e Analysis? and an ?Alternative Scenario Off-site Consequence Analysis? were performed using RMP Comp.  Also as part of the analysis all public and environmental receptors within the toxic endpoint concentration radius of 0.14mg/L were identified.  

Emergency response is discussed in Section 9 of the RMP Submittal.  The facility has a detailed Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for their facility.  The purpose of this plan is to provide the means for rapidly determining the appropriate response for any emergency that may develop at the facility such as an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  The ERP outlines procedures for conducting scheduled drills of the emergency response plan.

The current owners have not owned the facility for five years and there have been no reportable releases since the change in plant ownership.  To prevent and/or minimize any potential future release of anhydrous ammonia, The facility is implementing a detailed Process Safety Management (PSM) level 3 program.  The PSM program provides extensive maintenance and operator/mechanic training to ensure system mechanical integrity is maintained for the life of the covered process.  The PSM program also incorporates administrative controls when modifications are made to the covered process (ammonia refrigeration system), so that the training and preventative maintenance programs are updated as the system expands and changes.

All recommendations resulting from the Process Hazard Analysis, Compliance Audits, Off-site Consequences Analysis, Incident Investigations, and Mechanical Integrity Inspections will be considered and implemented if deemed necessary and feasible.  The flexibility of the program allows the facility to respond effectively to prevent or minimize any potential of exposing employees, the surrounding public, and/or the environment receptors to a release of anhydrous ammonia.
